references.name: Traction boards for vehicle recovery
references.description: Essential equipment for unsticking dual-wheel vehicles from soft terrain

image_suggestions: Photo comparison: Single tire vs dual tire motorhome rear axle
Diagram showing why dual tires get stuck easier in soft terrain (sand, mud)
Photo of dual-tire motorhome stuck in sand
Illustration of proper recovery technique for dual-wheel vehicles
enrichments.extra_info: Dual wheels (also called dualies or twin wheels) distribute weight better on paved roads and provide redundancy if one tire fails. However, they create more ground pressure on soft surfaces because the two tires on each side create a narrow 'track' rather than spreading load. Most expedition and overland motorhomes avoid dual wheels for this reason. Recovery requires lifting both tires simultaneously or placing boards under both wheels.

enrichments.extra_info: Proper winterization prevents thousands in damage from frozen pipes, fuel degradation, and battery sulfation. Key steps include draining all water systems, adding antifreeze to drains, disconnecting batteries (or using a trickle charger), over-inflating tires slightly, filling fuel tank to prevent condensation, adding fuel stabilizer, and using mechanical mouse traps (never poison as you won't find dead mice). Store in covered location if possible. Check on vehicle monthly if feasible.

enrichments.extra_info: Water tanks should be sanitized at least twice a year, or whenever the motorhome has been idle for weeks. enrichments.title: Windshield Crack Management - When to Replace vs Wait
image_suggestions: Diagram showing static vs dynamic crack types
Photo tutorial: How to mark crack edges to monitor growth
Chart showing temperature ranges and crack expansion risk
Photo of crack in driver's field of vision vs outside it
enrichments.extra_info: Windshield cracks are classified as static (non-growing) or dynamic (expanding over time). Mark crack endpoints with a marker and monitor daily - if it grows, replace immediately. Cracks in the driver's direct line of sight fail inspection and are dangerous. Temperature differentials (especially during storage or winter) can cause small cracks to expand rapidly. Cost of replacement varies: €200-600 for standard motorhomes, €400-1000+ for vehicles with lane-keeping assist or HUD systems requiring calibration.

references.description: Professional-grade fuel-resistant sealant for diesel systems (-60°F to 500°F range)

Photo of bleeding procedure for diesel fuel system
Step-by-step visual guide to finding air leaks using clear tubing

enrichments.extra_info: Air in diesel fuel systems causes power loss, rough running, and difficulty starting. Common entry points include degraded O-rings, loose connections, and hairline cracks in fuel lines. The bleeding procedure typically involves: 1) Crack open bleed screws on fuel filter, 2) Use hand primer pump until fuel flows bubble-free, 3) Tighten bleed screws, 4) Start engine and run until smooth. Permatex PermaShield ($8-12) is the gold standard sealant for diesel systems. If air keeps returning, inspect all connections with clear tubing segments to visually identify bubbles.

enrichments.extra_info: Battery disconnect switches prevent parasitic drain during storage and provide emergency shutoff capability. Three main types: 1) Mechanical switches on battery terminal (simple, reliable), 2) Quick disconnects (convenient but can bend/fail), 3) Panel-mounted heavy-duty switch (best accessibility). Recommended approach: Install main disconnect in accessible control panel (275A+ rating) plus mega-fuse near battery as backup. Proper sizing critical: 100A minimum for small systems, 200-275A for systems with inverters. Always disconnect negative terminal first when working on electrical systems.

enrichments.title: Gray Water Management in Cold Climate Travel
image_suggestions: Diagram showing gray water tank heating strategies
Photo of gray water discharge outlet at rear bumper
Temperature chart showing when gray water freezing becomes a risk
Illustration of insulated fresh water system vs exposed gray water system
enrichments.extra_info: Cold weather gray water management requires proactive strategies to prevent freezing. Best practices: 1) Pour hot water into gray tank in evening (instead of morning showers) to maintain temperature overnight, 2) Use diesel heating to warm water, 3) In extreme cold, keep gray valve open (non-legal in some areas but prevents tank freezing - wastewater drains directly), 4) Ensure fresh water tanks are in heated/insulated areas. Gray water discharge outlets typically located at rear bumper. Legal considerations: Gray water disposal regulations vary by country - some allow roadside disposal, others require designated dump stations. Always check local regulations.
